## PHYSICS

Paper 4 Theory (Extended)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 488]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 260, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 361, 530]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 is the top view of a rectangular paddling pool of constant depth. The pool is filled with sea water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A student carries out an experiment to determine the thermal capacity of a metal block. The block is heated by an electric heater for 23 minutes. The current in the heater is 3.0A at a potential difference (p.d.) of 12V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 606, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 512, 166]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 304, 920, 322]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
1. Two metal spheres of different diameters are heated to \(900^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) in a hot oven. The two spheres are removed from the oven.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
State and explain any difference in the initial rates of emission of radiation of thermal energy between the two spheres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 569, 539]]<|/det|>
2. One hot sphere is now heated in a hotter oven.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
State and explain any effect on the rate of emission of radiation of thermal energy from that sphere when it is removed from the hotter oven.

Fig. 7.1 shows a coil of wire wound on a thin plastic cylinder. The plastic has no effect on any magnetic field. The galvanometer is extremely sensitive.
